title: Stdin in std::io - Rust
markdown:
# Stdin in std::io - Rust

## Struct [std](../index.html)::[io](index.html)::[Stdin](#)

1.0.0 Â· [source](about:blank/src/std/io/stdio.rs.html#243-245) Â·

```
pub struct Stdin { /* private fields */ }
```

Expand description

A handle to the standard input stream of a process.

Each handle is a shared reference to a global buffer of input data to this process. A handle can be `lock`â€™d to gain full access to [`BufRead`](trait.BufRead.html "trait std::io::BufRead") methods (e.g., `.lines()`). Reads to this handle are otherwise locked with respect to other reads.

This handle implements the `Read` trait, but beware that concurrent reads of `Stdin` must be executed with care.

Created by the [`io::stdin`](fn.stdin.html "fn std::io::stdin") method.

#### [Â§](#note-windows-portability-considerations)Note: Windows Portability Considerations

When operating in a console, the Windows implementation of this stream does not support non-UTF-8 byte sequences. Attempting to read bytes that are not valid UTF-8 will return an error.

In a process with a detached console, such as one using `#![windows_subsystem = "windows"]`, or in a child process spawned from such a process, the contained handle will be null. In such cases, the standard libraryâ€™s `Read` and `Write` will do nothing and silently succeed. All other I/O operations, via the standard library or via raw Windows API calls, will fail.

## [Â§](#examples)Examples

```
use std::io;

fn main() -> io::Result<()> {
    let mut buffer = String::new();
    let stdin = io::stdin(); // We get `Stdin` here.
    stdin.read_line(&mut buffer)?;
    Ok(())
}
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Ause+std::io;%0A%0Afn+main()+-%3E+io::Result%3C()%3E+%7B%0A++++let+mut+buffer+=+String::new();%0A++++let+stdin+=+io::stdin();+//+We+get+%60Stdin%60+here.%0A++++stdin.read_line(%26mut+buffer)?;%0A++++Ok(())%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](about:blank/src/std/io/stdio.rs.html#342-422)[Â§](#impl-Stdin)

1.0.0 Â· [source](about:blank/src/std/io/stdio.rs.html#365-369)

Locks this handle to the standard input stream, returning a readable guard.

The lock is released when the returned lock goes out of scope. The returned guard also implements the [`Read`](trait.Read.html "trait std::io::Read") and [`BufRead`](trait.BufRead.html "trait std::io::BufRead") traits for accessing the underlying data.

##### [Â§](#examples-1)Examples

```
use std::io::{self, BufRead};

fn main() -> io::Result<()> {
    let mut buffer = String::new();
    let stdin = io::stdin();
    let mut handle = stdin.lock();

    handle.read_line(&mut buffer)?;
    Ok(())
}
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Ause+std::io::%7Bself,+BufRead%7D;%0A%0Afn+main()+-%3E+io::Result%3C()%3E+%7B%0A++++let+mut+buffer+=+String::new();%0A++++let+stdin+=+io::stdin();%0A++++let+mut+handle+=+stdin.lock();%0A%0A++++handle.read_line(%26mut+buffer)?;%0A++++Ok(())%0A%7D&edition=2021)

1.0.0 Â· [source](about:blank/src/std/io/stdio.rs.html#398-400)

Locks this handle and reads a line of input, appending it to the specified buffer.

For detailed semantics of this method, see the documentation on [`BufRead::read_line`](about:blank/trait.BufRead.html#method.read_line "method std::io::BufRead::read_line").

##### [Â§](#examples-2)Examples

```
use std::io;

let mut input = String::new();
match io::stdin().read_line(&mut input) {
    Ok(n) => {
        println!("{n} bytes read");
        println!("{input}");
    }
    Err(error) => println!("error: {error}"),
}
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::io;%0A++++%0A++++let+mut+input+=+String::new();%0A++++match+io::stdin().read_line(%26mut+input)+%7B%0A++++++++Ok(n)+=%3E+%7B%0A++++++++++++println!(%22%7Bn%7D+bytes+read%22);%0A++++++++++++println!(%22%7Binput%7D%22);%0A++++++++%7D%0A++++++++Err(error)+=%3E+println!(%22error:+%7Berror%7D%22),%0A++++%7D%0A%7D&edition=2021)

You can run the example one of two ways:

-   Pipe some text to it, e.g., `printf foo | path/to/executable`
-   Give it text interactively by running the executable directly, in which case it will wait for the Enter key to be pressed before continuing

1.62.0 Â· [source](about:blank/src/std/io/stdio.rs.html#419-421)

Consumes this handle and returns an iterator over input lines.

For detailed semantics of this method, see the documentation on [`BufRead::lines`](about:blank/trait.BufRead.html#method.lines "method std::io::BufRead::lines").

##### [Â§](#examples-3)Examples

```
use std::io;

let lines = io::stdin().lines();
for line in lines {
    println!("got a line: {}", line.unwrap());
}
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::io;%0A++++%0A++++let+lines+=+io::stdin().lines();%0A++++for+line+in+lines+%7B%0A++++++++println!(%22got+a+line:+%7B%7D%22,+line.unwrap());%0A++++%7D%0A%7D&edition=2021)

Settings

Struct std::io::Stdin

1.0.0 Â· source Â· 
pub struct Stdin { /* private fields */ }
Expand description

A handle to the standard input stream of a process.

Each handle is a shared reference to a global buffer of input data to this process. A handle can be lockâ€™d to gain full access to BufRead methods (e.g., .lines()). Reads to this handle are otherwise locked with respect to other reads.

This handle implements the Read trait, but beware that concurrent reads of Stdin must be executed with care.

Created by the io::stdin method.

Â§Note: Windows Portability Considerations

When operating in a console, the Windows implementation of this stream does not support non-UTF-8 byte sequences. Attempting to read bytes that are not valid UTF-8 will return an error.

In a process with a detached console, such as one using #![windows_subsystem = "windows"], or in a child process spawned from such a process, the contained handle will be null. In such cases, the standard libraryâ€™s Read and Write will do nothing and silently succeed. All other I/O operations, via the standard library or via raw Windows API calls, will fail.

Â§Examples

use std::io;

fn main() -> io::Result<()> {
    let mut buffer = String::new();
    let stdin = io::stdin(); // We get `Stdin` here.
    stdin.read_line(&mut buffer)?;
    Ok(())
}
Run

ImplementationsÂ§

sourceÂ§

impl Stdin

1.0.0 Â· source

pub fn lock(&self) -> StdinLock<'static> â“˜

Locks this handle to the standard input stream, returning a readable guard.

The lock is released when the returned lock goes out of scope. The returned guard also implements the Read and BufRead traits for accessing the underlying data.

Â§Examples
use std::io::{self, BufRead};

fn main() -> io::Result<()> {
    let mut buffer = String::new();
    let stdin = io::stdin();
    let mut handle = stdin.lock();

    handle.read_line(&mut buffer)?;
    Ok(())
}
Run
1.0.0 Â· source

pub fn read_line(&self, buf: &mut String) -> Result<usize>

Locks this handle and reads a line of input, appending it to the specified buffer.

For detailed semantics of this method, see the documentation on BufRead::read_line.

Â§Examples
use std::io;

let mut input = String::new();
match io::stdin().read_line(&mut input) {
    Ok(n) => {
        println!("{n} bytes read");
        println!("{input}");
    }
    Err(error) => println!("error: {error}"),
}
Run

You can run the example one of two ways:

  • Pipe some text to it, e.g., printf foo | path/to/executable
  • Give it text interactively by running the executable directly, in which case it will wait for the Enter key to be pressed before continuing
1.62.0 Â· source

pub fn lines(self) -> Lines<StdinLock<'static>> â“˜

Consumes this handle and returns an iterator over input lines.

For detailed semantics of this method, see the documentation on BufRead::lines.

Â§Examples
use std::io;

let lines = io::stdin().lines();
for line in lines {
    println!("got a line: {}", line.unwrap());
}
Run
